The claim was assessed in the context of: s influence in preventing Tesla from selling cars directly to consumers in Texas.
The cited study by the auto dealers asso: which claimed that consumers save an average of $500 per car sold through the franchised dealer model, was examined and found to not compare dealership sales to online or phone sales conducted by Tesla.
The Texas franchise law: which prohibits direct sales from manufacturers to consumers, was highlighted as a factor in Tesla's inability to sell cars at their own showrooms in Texas.
The unique showroom requirements of Tesl: which necessitate smaller, high foot traffic locations for an effective education process on their electric technology, were presented as a reason why the traditional dealership model in Texas would not work for the company.
